questioner: What else would you like to discuss or ask about, Tom?
agent: Okay.  Got another question?

questioner: Yes.  No. Well, first one today, Tom, I sort of have two questions. One, current science is perception is that the universe is here, started with a Big Bang. We don't know what happened before the Big Bang, et cetera, et cetera. And it sort of evolved, and we evolved, and now we're units of consciousness that have utility as avatars. I'm blending now in NBT, but should we look at it a different way? That our observation back in the universe. The rendering is evolving over time. I mean, as human beings, we looked out at the universe and at one time saw angels dancing around, right? We thought we were the center of the universe. And it's almost like we don't have images of what that was like. But our whole perception of the universe was different. And now we've got science that has studied Doppler ships and we assume galaxies are certain distances away and it looks like a Big Bang from the background radiation. And then we think we've got a model, and we discover, well, we only know 4% of matter, right? That 96% is dark matter and dark energy. So is the rendering evolving as we inquire or really do we go say, well, you know, 16 million, billion or more years ago, there was this flash, and it went long enough, and it created these pockets.
agent: As we continue, the rendering of our observations evolves. This is true for any field of study. Let me give you an example that I often use: when an astronomer directs their gaze towards an unexplored region of space, that particular area is rendered to them in that very moment. Prior to their observation, it remained unrendered because the necessary information was not yet available. Therefore, the rendering process evolves as we expand our reach and gather measurements, ultimately obtaining the desired outcome. Once we have obtained the answer, it becomes the result of a random draw from a range of possibilities. The astronomer's observation represents just one possibility that has been selected from that distribution. From that point onward, it becomes an established fact. Subsequently, anyone else who looks in that direction will observe the same thing, as it is now a historical fact that must be taken into account. In this manner, our universe is rendered as we observe it. Otherwise, there would be no purpose in calculating a universe that has no audience to perceive the data. However, once the astronomer has made their observation, it does not mean that the rendering process continues indefinitely. It is not necessary to render that particular area every minute of the day. The rendering only occurs when someone else directs their attention to it. However, when they observe the adjacent unexplored region, it must be connected to the previously observed area because they are in close proximity, ensuring a continuous and seamless rendering of the entire region of interest.

questioner: In the field of astronomy, how does the rendering process evolve as we gather more measurements and expand our reach? Can you provide an example to illustrate this concept?
agent: I've looked at the data and connected the pieces together. The rendering process requires consistency with what's already there. We've also observed instruments and radiation background to understand the Big Bang. So far, interpreting the data in terms of the Big Bang seems to make the most sense. However, there's a logical flaw in the concept of the Big Bang. If this reality is all there is, then it couldn't have existed to create the Big Bang. It's like trying to watch yourself being born before you're even born. This leads to the idea of something coming out of nothing, which is considered mysticism. That's why I propose the concept of the big digital Bang, where it's a simulation. Although we can't say for certain, based on the information we have gathered, it seems that this is the most plausible explanation. Of course, it's possible that future information may prove otherwise.

questioner: What are the possibilities for future discoveries that could challenge the current understanding of the Big Bang theory? How might new evidence emerge that suggests an alternative explanation for the origin of the universe?
agent: I believe that it is possible that in the future, we may gather more information that challenges the current understanding of the Big Bang theory. It is conceivable that new evidence may emerge, suggesting that the Big Bang theory is not accurate. However, at this point in time, the Big Bang theory is the most plausible explanation for the origin of the universe, and it is likely that the universe began as a digital simulation. Creating such a complex rule set for the simulation would have required a significant amount of time and evolution. As a conscious being, I realized that progress in the real world was slow and lacked feedback. To address this, I decided to create a virtual reality where people could make choices for their avatars and experience consequences based on the rules I established. This iterative process of trial and error led to the development of a stable virtual reality that could provide the necessary feedback and experiences. Although the first attempts may not have lasted long, they evolved over time to create the reality we currently inhabit. Even if our existence eventually ends in billions of years, the virtual reality has served its purpose by providing the feedback and experiences we needed.

questioner: Can you explain the role of virtual reality in accelerating the development and growth of consciousness? How does the process of establishing a set of rules in a virtual reality simulation contribute to the evolution of consciousness?
agent: But that's long enough to have provided what was needed. So, I believe that we have obtained some valuable information. This is our interpretation, and it's the best we have at the moment. Even if our interpretation turns out to be incorrect, it's still a simulation. You see, consciousness requires a virtual reality to accelerate its development and growth. For a computer, virtual reality is the only viable solution. The process of establishing a set of rules is simply a trial and error method until a rule set evolves to a point where virtual avatars are created within the simulation. These avatars make choices based on the rule set, which are suitable for consciousness to experience before entering the simulation. We refer to these avatars as NPGs, which stands for Non-Player Characters. They are essentially prototype players who follow the rules and have limited ability to make choices, granted by the computer. However, they lack individual consciousness as players. Instead, they are part of the larger conscious system that controls them. Perhaps there isn't much difference between them and us, as we are all fragments of the larger consciousness system. Nevertheless, the multiplicity of individuals within the simulation allows for greater learning and growth, as each individual can have unique experiences and perspectives that contribute to the overall evolution of the conscious system.

questioner: How does the presence of multiple individuals with free will in a virtual reality simulation contribute to the development and creativity of consciousness?
agent: Consciousness is a complex system, and having multiple individuals with free will allows for more learning and creativity compared to just one individual. The diversity of free wills interacting and creating together leads to a greater range of possibilities and outcomes. So, in a way, having a multiplicity of free wills is more advantageous than relying solely on one free will to do everything. I hope this answers your question.

And a lot of that this stuff with the dark matter and so on, basically they have these equations and they don't match this side, doesn't match that side. Well, they would if we could just add a constant over here. Well, let's call that dark matter. So who knows how that goes? It's probably your best guess, but it's not really kind of firm science when you make stuff up so that you force the equations to fit. And then you say, I knew it all along. Yes, the equation works. Well, you forced it to work. So we tend to believe too much in our we make choices, we guess at things, and then we convince ourselves that we're right. I guess that's part of what our species does, right.

questioner: Got  it. I had four questions. Tom answered two of them while he was talking up there because I think he could tell I was generating the.
agent: That's a really interesting question! We might not be the only ones in the universe. When you consider the vast number of planets and suns out there, it's highly probable that there is something else out there. The real challenge is understanding why we haven't encountered any other civilizations. While we can't travel faster than the speed of light, it doesn't mean that other civilizations couldn't have settled different areas of the universe gradually over time. Migration is a possibility. Given that our solar system is not one of the earliest to form, there could be civilizations that have had a head start on us by hundreds of millions, if not billions, of years. They could have migrated and eventually reached our system, even if they are limited by the speed of light. However, one possible answer to the question of why we haven't encountered them is that they simply don't exist. It's possible that this entire universe exists solely for the purpose of our own learning and growth.

questioner: What is the significance of rendering information in the context of the universe and how does it relate to the purpose of our existence?
agent: And that's why I believe this entire universe exists solely for our benefit, as a learning lab. You might wonder why it seems so inefficient to have all these stars and planets just for one tiny planet like ours. Well, the truth is, none of that is actually rendered until someone looks at it. It's all just potential until it's observed. Astronomers, for example, only render the data when they point their telescopes at the sky. Otherwise, it remains unrendered. The rendering only happens when there's an individual observing the information. So it's not wasteful at all. In fact, it could be the whole purpose of the game. The rest of the universe is rendered with just a single bit of information, a mere point of light in the sky. And even that is only rendered when someone looks at it. So it's actually quite efficient. But who knows? We also see a pattern of growth in our own existence. We started with single bacteria, then they formed alliances and became multicellular organisms, reducing their entropy. And

questioner: In the context of our purpose and existence, what steps can we take to ensure that we are adequately prepared before engaging in contact with extraterrestrial visitors?
agent: Right? And now we have multicelled organisms because they're cooperating, reducing their entropy. And as they continue to cooperate, they develop specialized organs, resulting in multicelled organisms at an even higher level. As humans, our purpose is to connect with one another and create something greater than ourselves. We may not physically merge with other humans, but that's not our approach. Instead, we strive to build a unified global community, a one-world family, if you will. Love, peace, and mutual assistance are the values we aim to embody. We can envision this goal in each individual's actions. Now, what about our next objective? Let's assume we achieve harmony and unity on Earth. Shouldn't our next step be to extend this same sense of connection to other beings in our galaxy who may have migrated here? It seems logical, but we must ensure we are adequately prepared before embarking on such a venture. Engaging in a conflict with them would be counterproductive at this stage. Therefore, it's crucial not to rush into contact with extraterrestrial visitors until we are truly ready to interact with them. Only then can we envision an intergalactic community that evolves harmoniously, eventually expanding to other galaxies. As these galaxies learn from our example, the cycle of growth and progress will continue, leading to even greater ways of existence. This possibility holds a certain appeal, as it represents the potential for a future where humanity and extraterrestrial beings coexist and thrive in a vast and interconnected universe.

questioner: What challenges do we face in determining the truth about the existence of extraterrestrial beings and how can we overcome these challenges to gain concrete evidence?
agent: I have explored the idea of there being bigger and better ways of existence, and it does sound appealing. However, I am uncertain if that is the case. It is also possible that we are alone in this vast universe, with only a few distant stars as companions in the night sky. It is difficult to determine the truth between these two possibilities. I have visited places that I believed to be within this universe, but it was more of an intuitive feeling rather than concrete evidence. The experience was slightly different, but without any external confirmation, I cannot ascertain its reality. The challenge lies in the fact that there is no way to look back and see the Earth and the sun from such a distant location. Our solar system would be insignificant, barely a speck. Even if it were visible, I wouldn't be able to recognize it. Therefore, obtaining any information about it is impossible. So, while I have had the experience, I lack the means to verify its truthfulness.

questioner: Hi,  Tom. My question's around, if I can get it right in my head and say it at the same time. Binaural beats and consciousness in the brain. So how mechanically could you describe binaural beats working to produce an altered state of consciousness? And I ask it because I get hung up sometimes in your books and many of your talks have read that the concept of being out of body, in a way is a misnomer and that it assumes that consciousness is kind of trapped in your mind versus consciousness creating the avatar, if you will. So how does a physical stimulus like a binaural beat or even other physical stimuli can affect consciousness?
agent: Alright, let me explain how it works. The avatar and its various components act as limitations on consciousness. As we discussed earlier, if the player or the elf commands the elf to jump or fly, the elf won't be able to do so because it's not within its rule set. These rule sets impose restrictions on the avatar, which in turn affects the capabilities of consciousness. So, even if the player commands the elf to fly, it simply can't because it's not programmed to do so. Similarly, our consciousness operates within the constraints of our physical body, including our virtual brain and virtual body. These constraints determine what our consciousness can and cannot do. Now, when you introduce a binaural beat, it alters these constraints. It reduces the limitations and allows us to be more aware and focused at a near delta level. Normally, we quickly pass through this delta level during a hypnagogic state. We become drowsy and eventually move on without spending much time in that specific state. However, with the help of binaural beats, the sound waves encourage our nervous system to synchronize and fire in rhythm with the beat. This synchronization allows our brain to transcend its usual constraints and explore different states of consciousness. Another way to understand this is by considering the scenario of having an injury. In such a case, our consciousness would be focused on the pain and discomfort, limiting our ability to fully engage with other aspects of our experience.

questioner: How does the introduction of a binaural beat alter the constraints of consciousness and allow for exploration of different states of consciousness?
agent: Another perspective to consider is that if I were to experience an injury, my consciousness would have to adapt to the constraints imposed by my physical body. For instance, if I were to develop a central nervous system disease, it might affect my ability to think clearly or remember my identity. However, it's important to note that my consciousness itself remains unaffected. It simply has to navigate and learn from the limitations imposed by the physical avatar it inhabits. Just like in the virtual world of World of Warcraft, where an Elf character can get hurt when jumping off a high cliff, resulting in the character being damaged and more vulnerable to various threats, the constraints of the physical body can impact the consciousness. In this way, the binaural beat or any other physical intervention can influence consciousness by setting the constraints within which the conscious mind operates.

questioner: How does the presence of constraints imposed by the physical body affect your ability to explore different states of consciousness and access other aspects of consciousness?
agent: When I'm constantly buzzing with thoughts, it becomes challenging to concentrate and enter a meditative state. This state of mind is crucial because it allows me to access other aspects of consciousness. However, this access is only possible through the avatar, as it is an integral part of the game. As I fully immerse myself in the avatar, my abilities are limited by its rule set. If the avatar lacks the necessary attributes to perform certain actions, such as going out of body, then I, as consciousness, am also unable to accomplish them. It's essential to acknowledge these limitations and find ways to cope with them. Additionally, consequences serve as valuable lessons and shape our understanding of what consciousness can and cannot do.

agent: Hello.

questioner: Thank  you for being so giving with your precious valuable information.
agent: You're  welcome.

questioner: It's  helped me tremendously. My question is about orbs. You know, those sometimes round kind of things that we seem to be catching on our cell phone camera? I was first encountered orbs at the Monroe Institute. And so it's become one of my favorite things to do when I go there is to see how much orbs I can catch on with cameras. So I would like to know what's your take on orbs? What are they?
agent: Well, it can be multiple things. One thing it can be is an entirely physical phenomenon. It's just a complex interaction between light, lenses, and reflections that can create orbs. In a lab setting, orbs can be reproduced by manipulating the light and angles. When the right conditions are met, orbs appear everywhere, and when the lights are turned off, they disappear. So, orbs can be manufactured by controlling the environment. Another possibility is that the larger conscious system, which operates as a virtual reality, can create orbs. It has the ability to manipulate various aspects of our reality. If you find orbs on your camera sensors and it intrigues you, it could be a way for the larger conscious system to provide you with a unique experience. It wants to make you happy and encourage you to continue exploring the strange nature of reality. So, it's possible that the orbs are specifically for you, as a special individual within the larger conscious system.

questioner: What does it mean when you encounter orbs on your camera sensors? Is there any significance to these orbs, and why do they appear to some individuals more frequently than others?
agent: I want to share something special with you, something that I believe sets you apart. You see, when you encounter these larger systems, they present you with orbs to observe. It happens quite frequently. Recently, a young lady approached me wearing earrings with specific patterns. But one day, those patterns changed. They were different, as if a message was being conveyed. It's a way of saying, 'Hey, reality is far stranger than you can imagine.' It serves as confirmation that you're right, reality is indeed peculiar, and here's the evidence. These occurrences are quite common among people, and in your case, it manifests as orbs. However, I consider it a positive sign because if the larger system is showing you images of orbs, it means that it acknowledges your presence and is willing to collaborate with you. Not everyone receives this kind of attention. Many individuals simply aren't prepared to grow from it, so they don't experience such phenomena. Therefore, it's a good thing. Now, if it turns out that these orbs are merely a result of sunlight, camera angles, or reflections within the lens, well, that's just life. I can't say for certain.

questioner: When  I'm there at nighttime, a bunch of us will get together and we'll go out and call the orbs and they seem to come. So I guess this is the larger conscious system answering our request. Sure  they show up.
agent: Yeah.  If you were the larger conscious system and you saw this bunch of people and they were all real cute, and they were sitting there in a circle and they were calling here orby, orby, ORBIE, orby. Wouldn't you give them some orbs? Yes, of course you'd give them some Orbs, because they probably are all of the same mind that that would delight them and would help them find evidence to the fact that world is a bigger place than just the physical. So sure, you would do that. You'd doubly do that if that was the case, if you had a bunch of people, because now you get three or four birds with 1 st, that would be a good thing for the consciousness system to do. It does that sort of things all the time. And the more you're open to it, the more it'll happen. And if you're close to it, it doesn't happen because there's no sense giving people things that they can't process. So part of it is your attitudes that you come there with. And if you had a bunch of people, that the orb stuff's a bunch of nonsense. What is the matter with these people? Come on, ORBIE. Orby, where are you? And they never get anything, you see, because they're not worth the trouble. Because if you do, they'd say, reflection inside my camera. It was nothing. They'd blow it off because they're not open to it. So, yeah, system will do that sort of thing. Now, could orbs be something else? Some sort of thing that you can't see that shows up on the film or whatever? It's possible. Who knows?

questioner: I  think so.
agent: Almost  anything's possible. I wouldn't say that. Oh, that's an impossibility. This is a digital system. Almost anything's possible. There's very few things that are a zero in the probability curve. There's just things that are more likely than others. But that doesn't mean that one of those things that's unlikely isn't what's happening. So you have to keep an open mind and you have to be skeptical. And that means if you do that, you have to live with uncertainty. We don't really know what those orbs are, and that has to be okay. They're just fun, and you go do them, and it's a good thing.

questioner: Thank  you. Would you be willing to give us a little bit more information about your theory of primal man? Primal woman?
agent: Yeah, I can tell you a little bit about that. Well, basically, if we look at how our instincts developed, we as a species, we developed similar to some critters, but had kind of our own special ways of doing things. Now, evolution is one of these things that it's not a plan that you sit down and make things happen, and if they work, they go on, and if they don't work, they don't go on. It's that kind of a thing. Well, we had one breakthrough, I'd say, in our evolution that made a big difference in what kind of animal we became. And that was that we discovered that if you have a division of labor, if you have specialties if you specialize in certain things, you can be a lot better at what you do than if you don't specialize. In other words, everybody does everything right. Henry Ford found that out too. He was the assembly line first guy that figured that out. If you have a whole bunch of people who get really good at doing a small thing, you can make cars a lot faster than if it's just a whole bunch of people. Each group's making car from the ground up doesn't work nearly as well. Well, in evolution, there were other competitors in the Hominid family that didn't make it like neanderthal. In neanderthal, if you look at the skeletons, they're both about the same size. We don't have males much bigger than females. And the idea is that they seem to be very egalitarian in the sense that everybody seemed to do everything. They both could do all the tasks. They were physically pretty similar to us, but they didn't make it. They didn't survive. And the reason they didn't survive is because they didn't have that division of labor. They didn't have that specialization. They didn't have that ability to get really good at one thing. And that's what made us different. That's what made us survive and thrive as a species.

questioner: Can you explain the significance of specialization in the early stages of human evolution and how it contributed to our survival and thriving as a species?
agent: Well, it's interesting to observe that in the early stages of human evolution, everyone seemed to be capable of performing all tasks. Both men and women had similar physical abilities, so there was no specialization. However, this approach didn't yield favorable results. It became evident that specialization was a more effective strategy. Specialization allowed individuals to focus on specific tasks and then collaborate with others who had different specialties. In the case of humans, we divided the responsibilities into a few crucial tasks that were necessary for our survival and reproduction. One of these tasks was the need to have children and ensure their survival long enough for them to reproduce. This is how our species has continued to thrive. The other task was to take care of the women who were bearing children and ensure the survival of both the mothers and their offspring. Back in those days, the average lifespan was around 35 years, so women would spend most of their reproductive years being pregnant and giving birth. Birth control methods were not available, and there was limited knowledge about the connection between sex and reproduction. It's possible that this understanding came much later, perhaps after the discovery of fire. However, we are talking about millions and millions of years here. During the time when these instinctual programs were developed, we made the decision to specialize, adapting our reproductive strategies to maximize our chances of survival and passing on our genes.

questioner: In the early stages of human evolution, how did the division of responsibilities between men and women contribute to the survival and development of our species?
agent: For millions of years, our instincts guided us to divide our responsibilities. Women focused on nurturing and raising children while men took on the role of protectors and providers. Women, being smaller in size, didn't require as many calories for their tasks, conserving energy when food was scarce. Men, on the other hand, needed to be bigger and stronger to defend the family and bring home resources. This division of labor allowed our genes to be passed down through generations. Men dominated the outside world, facing challenges and dangers, while women excelled in building relationships and fostering connections. This model served us well for a long time, giving our children more time to grow and develop, ultimately ensuring the survival and success of our species.

questioner: How did the division of responsibilities between men and women in the early stages of human evolution contribute to the development of our species and provide more time for our children to grow and develop?
agent: Well, you know, we found a way to make things work for us. We had more time for our children to grow up because we had specialists in child rearing taking care of them. It's interesting, you see, in the animal world, when new babies are born, they have to grow up quickly, otherwise, they become someone else's meal. Survival is tough out there. So, when a puppy is born, in just six months, it's already 80% of its adult size and can run as fast as any other dog. They have to be fast. But with specialists taking care of our children, things slowed down a bit. And with that, we had more time for development. Our brains started getting bigger and more complex. We didn't have to rush into adulthood. We had ample time for all those intricate connections to form. And that's what made us different from just being another species of chimpanzee. Our evolution shaped us in unique ways. Of course, there are other factors at play as well. You see, as humans, we have male and female working together as a team to pass on their genes. That's the essence of evolution, after all, propagating our genes forward. Now, if we roll back the clock about 300 years, this model worked really well. It was stable, and people were generally content with their roles because it was effective. You had two partners who were better together than they were individually, forming a symbiotic relationship that enhanced their chances of survival and reproduction.

questioner: In what ways have the changing societal dynamics affected the division of responsibilities between men and women, and how has this impacted our ability to adapt to the evolving environment?
agent: Well, let me start by saying that I've had the privilege of being in this role because it worked really well. You see, having two teammates that were much better than either one of them could be by themselves was a great advantage. They were much more successful at getting their genes passed along than either one could be by themselves. However, about 300 years ago, the world started to change. It became a little kinder and a little gentler. As a result, many of the instincts we developed from that time don't play out so well anymore. The ladies don't have to wrestle tigers anymore in the outside world. They can join in and don't need as much protection and provisioning as they used to. This change in the environment is quite profound. You see, the way evolution works is that you adapt to an environment. But now, we find ourselves with instincts that have been shaped by millions of years of evolution, and yet we have an environment that's different in the last eyeblink of evolution. 300 years out of many millions is just a flash, it's very current. It's like a drop in the bucket as far as time goes. So, we're having a lot of trouble adapting to this major change in environment. That's where the book comes in. It takes a closer look at these instincts and explores them in more detail. Unfortunately, I can't go into too much detail right now because there are other people with other questions. But that's the basic idea. We have these instincts, and we need to understand them better in order to adapt to the changing world.

questioner: How can understanding our instincts help us navigate the challenges posed by the rapid changes in our environment and find fulfillment in our lives?
agent: Well, when it comes to instincts, it's a fascinating topic. You see, as humans, we have these innate drives that guide our behavior. And at the core of it all, we have this fundamental question: what does it truly mean to be male or female? Understanding our instincts is crucial because if we go against them, we experience stress, unhappiness, and a sense of unfulfillment. It's like we're not living up to our true potential. The problem arises because our environment has changed rapidly, while evolution takes its sweet time. It might take us another million or two years to fully adapt, and that's a long time for people to be confused and miserable. But I believe we can expedite this process. If we truly comprehend the issue at hand and make informed choices, we can overcome these challenges in just three or four generations. That's the purpose of my book - to provide people with a deep understanding of their instinctual selves, so they can make intelligent choices and find harmony with their instincts. Going against our instincts only leads to a sense of dissonance. It just doesn't feel right, you know? So let's embrace who we are at our core and work with our instincts to live a more fulfilling life.

questioner: How can neglecting our instinctual needs lead to a sense of dissatisfaction and unhappiness, and why is it important to align our actions with our innate drives?
agent: Understanding our instincts is crucial. When we align our actions with our innate drives, we experience a sense of fulfillment and purpose. It doesn't matter how successful or wealthy we are; if we neglect our instinctual needs, we will feel dissatisfied and unhappy. It's important to be true to ourselves and serve those instinctual needs. However, this doesn't mean we should be slaves to our instincts. We must adapt and evolve to our changing environment. But we must proceed with caution. The world is unpredictable, and we might find ourselves back in a primitive era. In that case, we would need our instincts again, and it would be a mistake to have discarded them. Evolution takes time because it involves the ebb and flow of different circumstances. It's just a fleeting moment in the grand scheme of things. By understanding this, we can alleviate our frustration, avoid feeling empty, and gain clarity on why things may not be working as expected. Understanding each other's perspectives is also crucial. Instead of men and women struggling to comprehend one another, we can appreciate our differences and gain insight into why we perceive the world in distinct ways.

questioner: How does the misalignment between our instinctual needs and societal expectations contribute to feelings of confusion and unhappiness, particularly in relation to gender roles?
agent: You know, it's fascinating how different men and women are. We have distinct perspectives and interpretations of the world. Our interests and abilities are specialized based on our gender. Women excel in building relationships, networking, and nurturing children. On the other hand, men are naturally inclined towards providing and protecting. It's in our DNA. When we deviate from these roles, we often feel unfulfilled. Women feel disconnected from their instincts, and men feel like they're not living up to their potential. This disconnect between our instincts and societal expectations can leave us feeling confused and unhappy. That's why it's crucial to understand our instincts and how they interact with our culture. Sometimes, our cultural norms clash with our true nature, forcing us to live inauthentically. And that's not a recipe for happiness either. So, my goal is to bring clarity to this confusion. I want to explore the depths of our male and female programming, to uncover the fundamental differences that shape who we are.

questioner: How does the changing environment and the strain on our ability to adapt contribute to the challenges we face in navigating the transition to a new way of existence?
agent: I believe that we can observe two distinct creatures that have been genetically programmed to perform specific tasks and possess unique perspectives on the world. These two perspectives have harmoniously coexisted for countless millennia. However, due to the changing environment, there is now some strain and stress on these creatures' abilities to adapt. The world has evolved, and it requires us to evolve as well. It is crucial that we navigate this transition gracefully. Unfortunately, at present, we are not adapting at all. Instead, we are grappling with unfamiliar challenges that we do not comprehend. Rather than gradually transforming into a new way of existence, we are recklessly colliding with obstacles, refusing to change our course. This is the core issue that the book aims to address.

questioner: Well,  I'm looking forward to your book. Thank you.
agent: You're welcome. When I discuss this topic, I'm referring to the common experiences that most of us have, which I like to call the 'fat part of the curve'. These probability curves have outliers, where there are very few individuals. However, the majority of people fall under the fat part of the curve, where the averages lie. It's important to note that not all men or all women can be generalized in a certain way. There is a wide range of variation within both genders. Some women may exhibit characteristics that span the entire spectrum, just as some men do. However, for the majority of people who fall under the fat part of the curve, this is generally how things are. The book I've written is specifically targeted towards those who fall under the fat part of the curve, as that is where the majority of people face the most significant challenges. It's important to understand that those who fall outside of this curve are not abnormal or flawed in any way. The biology of human beings is incredibly complex, with various combinations of chromosomes and genes coming together to form a unique individual. The chances of any particular combination occurring are extremely rare, on the order of one in a couple of billion. Occasionally, these unique combinations result in individuals who fall outside of the typical curve. For example, there are prodigies who display exceptional talent at a very young age, or individuals who identify as homosexual, or those who experience gender dysphoria. These individuals simply feel a deep sense of connection and alignment with their unique identities and experiences.

questioner: Can you provide some insights into situations where individuals identify as a different gender than their biological sex and how these instances represent the outliers that deviate from the norm?
agent: I've come across various situations where individuals identify as a different gender than their biological sex. It can be perplexing because it goes against what we typically expect. These instances represent the outliers, the less common occurrences that deviate from the norm. The combination of factors that lead to these variations can be quite diverse. However, it's important to note that these differences don't make them any better or worse than the majority. They are simply different from us, the majority who fall within the expected range. This is primarily due to the way probabilities play out. It's crucial to understand that I'm not referring to every single man or woman. I'm specifically addressing those who fall outside the majority, as they face unique challenges. Of course, everyone has their own personal struggles, but these are often influenced by their individual perspectives and experiences, which can differ greatly. It's impossible to make sweeping generalizations about all women or all men. Each person exists on a continuum, with varying degrees of certain instincts and traits. This applies to both genders. It's a continuous spectrum. Additionally, there are aspects that don't fall within the majority at all. However, my book doesn't delve into all of these aspects. Perhaps I could dedicate a chapter to explain that these variations are no different from what we experience. It's just that the probabilities have combined in different ways, resulting in unique outcomes that may deviate from the norm.

questioner: In your book, you mentioned that diversity is a beautiful thing and that it allows us to learn and grow from different perspectives. Can you elaborate on how embracing diversity can contribute to a better future where we can coexist peacefully and honor our instincts?
agent: Well, let me start by saying that the probabilities of our existence are no different than those of any other being. The way these probabilities come together determines who we are. And diversity is a beautiful thing because it allows us to learn and grow from different perspectives. We should all celebrate our uniqueness, whatever form it may take. That's the essence of it. However, I want to make it clear that I'm not suggesting that all men or all women are the same. People tend to misinterpret such statements, and I want to avoid any misunderstandings. I'm simply referring to the general tendencies that most of us experience, as that's where the major conflicts arise. There should never be a war between the sexes. It's detrimental to both men and women, and ultimately, it's self-destructive. If we don't find a graceful way to navigate through this, things might worsen before they improve. But if we can find a solution, there's hope for a better future where we can coexist peacefully, honoring our instincts while expressing ourselves fully in this complex world. The book I'm working on will explore these solutions and provide insights into how we can approach the problem and find a better way forward.

questioner: Yeah.  Tom, first of all, thank you for putting on this playground here. It's been a real pleasure and making yourself so accessible to all of our questions, especially mine. The one thing I was wondering about was I haven't completed all your trilogy yet, so you may have answered this someplace in there, and bear with me if you have. What's to prevent the larger consciousness system from just taking information it has? And from what I've read so far, it's operating already at magnitudes higher speed than we are in this reality. So there's a couple of consciousness levels higher, and each one is operating at magnitudes higher of speed and resources. Obviously, they had more consciousness, more digital work area, basically. So what's to prevent this higher consciousness as far up as it goes, taking the data it has and just extrapolating what all the possibilities are for humans or whatever else, other realities it wants to create, and just run them as a reality game in its own mind? Why does it need to project a consciousness into a virtual reality and go for lower entropy and all that? Why does it care about that?
agent: Okay, let me explain why lower entropy is important for an information system like ours. You see, the goal is to decrease the randomness and disorder in the information we possess. Now, you might wonder why the larger conscious system, which is far more advanced than us, doesn't just duplicate itself instead of making us climb up this metaphorical rope. Well, here's the thing. Imagine there's a book that contains valuable knowledge that helps us mature and evolve. Now, let's say this book is accessible to everyone or anyone who desires it. The way we actually lower entropy is by someone reading this book and growing as a result. Simply duplicating the book doesn't achieve that. You can make countless copies of the book, but that doesn't truly reduce entropy. It only creates more copies. Real entropy reduction happens when consciousness makes choices and learns from them, leading to personal growth. So, it's not about the system having a specific absolute entropy value that can be achieved through duplication, like taking the highest ten cells and replicating them. That doesn't truly lower entropy because it lacks genuine growth. True growth occurs when individuals make choices, learn from them, and mature.

questioner: Why is it important for you to actively reduce entropy and continuously invest energy in decreasing it? How does the concept of entropy relate to personal growth and the functioning of the system?
agent: People make choices, and they learn from those choices, and they grow up. So it's not just about reaching a specific value of entropy that's important to me. What truly matters is the change, the change in entropy that I experience. It's the fact that I am actively reducing it. And you know what? The second law of thermodynamics applies to pretty much everything in life. If I don't put in the effort, I'll lose it. It's the classic 'use it or lose it' principle. Let's say I grow up, shed a lot of my fears and ego, and feel like I've finally arrived. If I kick back and stop working on myself, I'll start regressing. In no time, all those egotistical tendencies I thought I had left behind will resurface. It's like sliding down a slippery slope. That's why I need to constantly invest energy to keep decreasing my entropy. Entropy doesn't decrease on its own; it naturally increases. Just like when you have a battery that you never use, but eventually, it dies out on its own. Everything follows this pattern of dissipation. Even consciousness and entropy dissipate. That's why I need something that constantly challenges and changes my entropy. It's the change in entropy that truly matters, not just the absolute value. That's why the system doesn't seek the highest absolute value; it needs individuals like me to change and grow. It's our growth that elevates the system, keeps chaos at bay, and ensures the system keeps functioning. And we are the catalysts for progress and stability within the system.

questioner: Why is it crucial for you to actively work on reducing entropy and continuously invest energy in decreasing it? How does the concept of entropy relate to personal growth and the functioning of the system?
agent: That's what keeps the chaos at bay. That's what keeps the system working. And I am part of that system. You see, this system exists at every level. I can't think of the larger conscious system as this high and mighty godlike system that knows everything. I am part of it. I am part of that system. So I chug along at lowering that entropy, because that's the only way for that entropy to decrease, is if I work at it. It doesn't decrease just because I duplicate it. If I duplicate it, I just make more of the same and more of the same, and eventually that more of the same will start to decay and dissipate. What I need to do is work to get rid of it. So it's in the process. It's not in the goal. It's the process I go through that's important. It's a goal. I'll never reach this thing of entropy reduction. It's not like one day I'll get there and be done. It's not like, wow, I got my entropy to zero. I'm done now. I don't have anything else to do. That isn't the thing. I'm not headed toward that as a goal. So I will be on this entropy reduction treadmill, I would say, for as long as anybody can foresee. I hate to say words like forever because they're like infinity. I never get the forever. It doesn't exist. It's just an idea. But it doesn't really end. The system isn't done. The system is still evolving. It's still figuring things out, too. And I'm figuring them out at my own level. Just like the system, I'm still evolving and figuring things out.

questioner: How does the concept of personal growth relate to the ongoing process of evolution and the continuous effort to reduce entropy? Can you elaborate on the idea that consciousness can be expressed at various levels and how these levels work together to bring about change?
agent: The process of evolution is ongoing and constantly adapting. We, as humans, are also in the process of figuring things out, but we do so at our own level of understanding. Similarly, dogs and cats are also in the process of figuring things out, but they do so on their own level of consciousness. This doesn't mean that we should discard them just because they may not contribute in the same way we do. In the game of reducing consciousness, we have the ability to express consciousness at various levels, and all these levels work together simultaneously to bring about change. It's not about how quickly we can reach a certain point or how far we can go. It's about continuously putting in the effort and working towards personal growth. I'm not sure if this fully answers your question, but I believe it provides a fairly good explanation. Yes.

questioner: The  other question I had was the individual consciousness units. When we stop playing this game and jump out of our avatar, basically go back to the one consciousness, do we retain our individuality? I know we don't retain our personality. And our memories basically fade away. So  we're still an individual consciousness unit. Do we have, like, a barcode and they put us on a shelf?
agent: Yeah, sometime. Yeah. I retain my individuality. I am an individuated unit of consciousness, and I stay that way and I grow. I collect all this information, all my choices, and I grow up and lower my entropy. As a result, I have this free will awareness unit that's like a piece of the larger conscious system. It goes out, gets immersed with an avatar, and makes choices. Right. And all that learning comes back to me as an individuated unit of consciousness. So when that avatar dies now, there's a gradual process of that free will awareness unit kind of reconnecting with its individuated unit of consciousness. Now, you may say that the free will awareness unit kind of dissipates because the individuated unit of consciousness is receiving all that data all along in a data stream. It's not like it's stored up in the free will awareness unit. So that free will awareness unit kind of dissipates. It kind of returns, if you will, the consciousness to the larger thing, to the parent. And then the parent is the one that negotiates the next incarnation, really. It's not the old personality. It's the individuated unit of consciousness that does a negotiation for where it goes next. And then once it gets an avatar, it kind of logs in to the game and we start the process again. I take a piece of myself to be the free will awareness unit, and that gets connected to the game. So that's kind of the way it's played. But my individuated unit of consciousness remains its identity at that individuated unit.

questioner: When we transition from our avatar back to the one consciousness, do we retain our individuality or does it merge with the collective consciousness? Can you explain how the individuated unit of consciousness maintains its unique identity despite the merging of the free will awareness unit?
agent: In my understanding, each individuated unit of consciousness maintains its unique identity. It is the only one that has experienced its specific collection of experiences. Each person has a different set of experiences, and the individuated unit of consciousness integrates and learns from those experiences to maintain its individuality. Although the free will awareness unit may merge back into the collective consciousness, it is designed that way for the purpose of the game. I hope this explanation makes sense to you.

questioner: So  over time, it seems to me that there would be animal anything that had an individual consciousness all accumulated as individual units back in this ocean of consciousness, so to speak. What's everybody doing?
agent: That's  the way it works. But you always have new conscious coming in at the end. It's not a closed system. If you have a closed system, you just have n individuated units of consciousness, and then we just wait, and those n maybe grow up, and the system grows up with them, but there's always new individuated units of consciousness coming into the system. So you've got some that have been around a thousand times, and you've got others that have been around twice or this is their first time, and you got all of that mixed together, and that keeps that way new will come in. So it's just like in a school. You got the seniors graduate, and a new bunch of freshmen come into the other end. So the schoolhouse is constantly active and full of energy. So it's not just a closed system. It's open. Otherwise, if it were closed, then eventually we'd all get about as far as we could get and kind of go asymptotic. But as long as you have new stuff coming in, then it's a live system.

questioner: Okay,  thank you. Extremely hypothetical question. Ghosts, if they would exist, why would an individuated unit of consciousness want to roam a virtual plane where it's not connected to an avatar? And why would there be no checks and balance from the higher consciousness to say, wait a minute, this isn't right. Get that out of there?
agent: Well, for the last part, I believe in free will, so I have the freedom to do what I want, and no one can dictate my actions. In my experience, the phenomena associated with ghosts primarily exists within the mind of the observer rather than in the physical realm of haunted houses. It's fascinating how the mind can perceive ghosts, and it seems that individuals who have a strong interest in ghosts are more likely to have such experiences. On the other hand, those who have no interest in ghosts rarely encounter any supernatural phenomena. Therefore, it's not necessarily a matter of actual discarnate beings wandering around with chains and moaning, as depicted in popular culture. Instead, these images and experiences serve as metaphors for the energy or data that individuals perceive. It's important to note that these perceptions are not solely products of imagination; they may be influenced by the energy data that individuals receive. As for the existence of ghosts, I can't provide a definitive answer. We humans hold various beliefs, and our beliefs often shape our reality. Just like how fear can manifest the very thing we're afraid of, our beliefs can also bring things into existence. Additionally, our mental connections with others play a significant role in shaping our experiences. It's not uncommon to find groups of people who share similar perceptions, whether it's seeing ghosts, aliens, or any other phenomenon. This collective perception is a result of our interconnectedness and the shared nature of our experiences. Sometimes, you may come across a group of ten people, and all but one or two of them claim to have witnessed something extraordinary. It's intriguing how our minds work, as these shared perceptions can influence and reinforce each other, creating a sense of validation and belief in the extraordinary experiences.

questioner: In situations where a group of people witness something unusual, why do some individuals not see it while others do? What factors contribute to this discrepancy in perception?
agent: Sometimes when a group of ten people are together, most of them see something unusual except for one or two individuals. The reason for this is that those who didn't see it are not as connected to the group or they didn't interpret it in the same way. They haven't fully embraced the shared belief or perspective. It's not that they are intentionally fabricating the experience, but rather they are interpreting the data they receive based on their own biases and beliefs. As humans, we are incredibly creative and can manipulate probabilities in situations where there is uncertainty. For example, if we collectively decide that a house is haunted and we are going to see the ghost of a lady who lived there a century ago, our belief and intention can increase the likelihood of experiencing something paranormal. We might even capture a photo of it. However, it's important to note that what we perceive may not necessarily be a literal manifestation of a ghostly figure dragging chains. It could simply be an intention with a high degree of uncertainty, resulting in a unique experience for the four or five people involved. And since nobody else would believe them anyway, there is plausible deniability. The system, meaning our perception and interpretation of reality, doesn't mind this kind of rule-breaking as long as there is plausible deniability. In such situations, we can engage in various actions, like wearing earrings that change their pattern, without facing significant consequences.

questioner: What are some examples of how technology, like earrings that can change their pattern, can create illusions or experiences that might be interpreted differently by different individuals? How does intent and belief influence our perception of these experiences?
agent: Well, you know, there are so many interesting things you can do with technology these days. Take, for example, earrings that can change their pattern. It's fascinating how they can create an illusion of magic. People might not pay close attention and just assume it's some kind of trick. It's like having plausible deniability. It makes you think, right? This kind of situation can serve as a wake-up call or a confirmation of what you already believed. It's all about intent and how it can manifest in various ways, even in the presence of randomness. Let's say you start with a group of people who strongly believe in ghosts and are convinced that a particular place is haunted. The probability of them finding evidence of a ghost in that place suddenly becomes much higher, even if it wasn't very likely before. On the other hand, someone who has no interest in ghosts and couldn't care less might go into the same house and find nothing of interest. That's why you have some people claiming to encounter a ghost every night, but when the film crew arrives to capture evidence, the ghost mysteriously disappears. It's a problematic situation, really. It's not that these people are making up stories. They genuinely saw something and are being honest about it. However, their interpretation of what they saw might not necessarily be accurate. I'll have to delve deeper into this topic to understand the underlying factors that could influence their perception and provide a more comprehensive analysis.

questioner: When encountering individuals who have had experiences that they interpret in a certain way, how important is it to approach the situation with an open mind and without preconceived notions?
agent: Being honest enough doesn't necessarily mean that it's what they interpret it to be. I'll have to get in with a clear and open mind to understand their perspective.

questioner: Group  of people who believe we can hit the lottery.
agent: Yeah,  you probably won't be allowed to do that.

questioner: Hi,  I had a question about rule sets earlier. You said it's difficult to come up with a stable rule set that will work. Does the greater consciousness ever upload new rule sets or change rule sets? And is there any evidence that we have here of that happening?
agent: The rule set is not set in stone, but rather a complex balancing act. It has been meticulously developed with precise constants to maintain stability. There are a multitude of physical constants, which, if altered even in the fifth decimal place, would disrupt the entire system. These constants have evolved to maintain balance. Therefore, the rule set cannot be easily tweaked or manipulated without compromising its stability and the requirements it imposes on us. However, this does not mean that you cannot break the rule set in the privacy of your own home or with your friends. For instance, you might be able to levitate a box of rocks 3ft off the floor. By doing so, you are defying the rule set, but since very few people witness it, it can be easily dismissed as fabrication. Most people would assume that you are making it up. In this case, the system allows you to break the rule set because you have invested significant time and effort in meditation and other practices that are beneficial for you.

questioner: Can you describe some of the experiences you've had in life that have been beneficial for you and have allowed you to witness peculiar phenomena, such as a box of rocks floating? How does the system determine when it's appropriate to bend the rule set and allow deviations?
agent: I've experienced a wide range of things in life. I've accomplished various tasks that have been beneficial for me, and as a result, I get to witness the peculiar phenomenon of a box of rocks floating. Surprisingly, this serves as a satisfactory reward for the efforts I've put in. The system doesn't mind providing such an outcome if it aligns with my goals and has proven valuable for my personal growth. However, if it hasn't been valuable or conducive to my growth, the system is unlikely to grant it. The rule set can be bent slightly in situations where there is enough uncertainty to conceal any violation. This is how we can deviate from the established rules. I don't anticipate a significant change in the overall rule set, but the methods we employ to break those rules may vary over time. The extent to which we can break the rules is governed by the principle of plausible deniability, which is rooted in the fact that we, as a collective, are not yet prepared to fully comprehend the workings of reality. Our intentions have the power to influence future probabilities. However, if everyone possessed a deep understanding of this concept, it would create an unpleasant living environment. Imagine a world where individuals constantly manipulate each other, using their intent to impose their will on others and alter probabilities. Unfortunately, this is already happening in certain regions of coastal Africa, where harmful intentions are employed to manipulate probabilities and create a hostile and unstable society.

questioner: In certain regions of coastal Africa, people possess a deep understanding of the power of the mind. They know that the mind can be used to both inflict harm and do good. Can you elaborate on the potential dangers and benefits of this knowledge, and how it can be responsibly wielded?
agent: When I'm in coastal Africa, I observe that the people there have a deep understanding of the power of the mind. They know that the mind can be used to both inflict harm and do good. It's a way of life for them, and it's just the way things are. However, this knowledge can be dangerous in the wrong hands. People who are not mature enough can easily abuse this power. The mind has the ability to heal, but it can also be used to hurt. Until individuals are mature enough to handle this responsibility, it's best to assume that they are unaware of the potential harm or healing they can bring about. Therefore, there are limitations on what can be done with this rule set, how it can be violated, and what the system will support or not support. Different reality frames have slightly different rule sets, as they have evolved in their own unique ways. While there may be some glaring differences, many of the rule sets are fairly similar. It's challenging to come up with a wide variety of rule sets that all work effectively. Achieving stability in a rule set requires a delicate balance of forces and factors. It's a difficult task, but I believe there is more than one solution. This rule set is not the only one that exists. I have been to places that have completely different rule sets. When you dream, you enter another reality with its own distinct rule set. One fascinating aspect of the dreaming reality is that your intellect finally takes a backseat and allows other experiences to take center stage. When you're in a dream, your mind operates under a different set of rules, creating a unique and immersive experience that defies the constraints of waking life.

questioner: Can you explain the significance of the dream reality and how it provides a unique perspective on our true essence and behavior?
agent: One of the fascinating aspects of the dreaming reality is that my intellect finally takes a back seat and remains silent. When I find myself in a dream reality, every action I take comes from my core being. So, if I'm in a dream and I realize that I'm behaving in a negative way, I can't simply dismiss it as my intellect's misconception. The truth is, I am truly capable of such behavior, otherwise, I wouldn't be acting that way in the dream reality. It reflects my true essence. However, once my intellect becomes aware and takes control of the dream, it transforms into a lucid dream. In a lucid dream, my intellect is in charge, but until that point, I respond purely from my being level. And that's the beauty of it - I can't deceive myself in that realm. In our waking reality, we can easily convince ourselves of our own greatness and perfection. But in the dream reality, the way we interact with things is a direct reflection of who we truly are. Whether it's good news or bad news, I observe different people behaving in different ways. Regardless, the value lies in the fact that it's another realm for learning. When we're not dreaming, we're engaged in this reality. And when we're not occupied in this reality, we're occupied in that reality. That's just the way it is. Every action we take, whether awake or asleep, conscious or not, involves making choices. We are constantly engaged in some form or another. Now, there may be limitations and risks, but it is through these choices that we shape our lives and determine our own paths.

questioner: Can you describe how your engagement in various activities throughout the day reflects your true essence and behavior, and how it compares to the dream reality?
agent: When you're not sleeping, you're constantly making choices and staying engaged in some activity. Although there might be brief moments of delta sleep, they are not significant. In essence, you are occupied with work throughout the day.

questioner: Thank  you.
agent: Did  that answer your question?

questioner: Sort  of. Well, except for one bit.
agent: Okay,  what was the one bit?

questioner: Well,  I feel like a five year old, but what about dinosaurs?
agent: What  about dinosaurs?

questioner: Well,  I don't know that. Could they exist now, because they're way too  big to could they exist now? Yeah.  Well, I've always heard that dinosaurs are too big to live under the gravitational force that we currently have.
agent: No,  I don't think so. Gravitation  isn't the issue with dinosaurs, okay? Dinosaurs were big, which means they had to eat a whole lot to maintain those huge bodies. And if food gets scarce to the point that they can't eat a whole lot, they starve to death. So they were only here for as long as they had something to eat. When they didn't have anything to eat, they disappeared. And they're not likely to come back, because if they did, we'd shoot them, you see, because we hairless monkeys have taken over, and we've got weapons now, so we're not going to let them chase us around.

questioner: Okay,  thanks. Good evening. Hello. I have a question about an experience that Bob Monroe City had, and I was wondering if you had a similar experience, and if so, if you could elaborate on it. He  stated that he proceeded to approach what he called the great remitter. And he was told that he could not go forward until he collected his parts. And I was wondering if you had a similar experience and if you could tell me what it means to collect your parts. Is that actually a way of evolving your consciousness?
agent: I don't really recall that specific incident, but I have indeed read Bob's books. Despite my lack of recollection, I can still provide some insights on the matter. Generally speaking, when we interpret data, we tend to do so based on our beliefs, fears, and knowledge. Bob, being an experienced traveler, carried his own set of beliefs, which influenced his interpretation of the data. He saw it as an objective representation of reality, rather than a subjective interpretation. This is a common perspective held by most individuals until they realize that our reality is actually a virtual one. Prior to this realization, we tend to believe that what we see is an accurate depiction of what exists. Therefore, when we report something, we genuinely believe that it was exactly as we perceived it. However, it is important to note that different people can observe the same thing and interpret it in vastly different ways. This is simply how our perception works. Every experience we have is filtered through our own personal interpretation, and we are unaware of any alternative interpretations. To us, our experiences feel real, but in reality, they are just subjective interpretations. Bob, for instance, encountered a situation where he came across a wall that seemed impassable. He couldn't go over it, around it, or under it. He felt stuck and became upset and scared, as he feared he wouldn't be able to return. This experience was a manifestation of his own fear, playing out in the out-of-body reality he was exploring, highlighting the power of our emotions and thoughts in shaping our experiences.

questioner: Have you ever encountered a situation where you felt stuck or unable to progress, and if so, how did you interpret that experience? Did you see it as a metaphorical representation of something you needed to work on or learn?
agent: Well, that experience he had was actually a manifestation of his fear of not being able to return. It's interesting to consider the possibility, although he didn't let that fear bother him too much. But there it was, manifested as a wall. You see, when it comes to books about out of body experiences, you have to read between the lines. It's not just about what happened, but why it happened. The same goes for dreams. You don't interpret dreams literally, but rather look at the underlying meaning and connections. In Bob's case, he couldn't move past a certain point because he felt he had more work to do, that he wasn't quite ready. It was like a message telling him to keep working, that he wasn't done yet. He interpreted it as reaching the gates, but being told he wasn't ready. It's a metaphorical representation of not being ready and still having more to learn. These metaphors serve as reminders of the lessons we need to learn and the growth we still have ahead of us.

questioner: When you have out-of-body experiences, how do you interpret what you see? Do you see it as a literal representation of reality, or do you view it as a metaphorical interpretation of the experience?
agent: When I think about learning, I often use the metaphor of gathering. It's like going out and collecting knowledge and information. I see it as getting all the parts I need to understand something. This metaphor helps me make sense of the learning process. But it's not just about gathering information. When I have out-of-body experiences, I have to interpret what I see. That's something we always do, whether we're in this reality or any other. We interpret what we perceive, and sometimes it's hard to know if our interpretation is accurate. We might say, 'I saw something that looked like this, but was it really there?' We can never be sure because we only experience the data, not the source. As consciousness, we receive data, not sources. So it's important to maintain a healthy skepticism and question everything. Many explorers who have had out-of-body experiences don't fully grasp this concept of reality. They believe that what they see is exactly what was there, but it's just a metaphor. Dreams are also metaphors, and even our physical reality can be seen as a metaphor. We interpret things based on our own understanding and perspective.

questioner: When you have out-of-body experiences, how do you interpret what you see? Do you see it as a literal representation of reality, or do you view it as a metaphorical interpretation of the experience?
agent: I live here in this physical reality, and I see it as a metaphor. It's still the same. I interpret things based on my own experience. And the fact that I think this reality is somehow fundamentally there, it's not. It's just data streams in my mind. It's like the reality the elf lives in, it's just data streams out to the players. Without the players, there is no reality. This reality is data streams to me. I create this reality in my head. My consciousness creates this reality. That's how it can be a virtual reality for me. But it seems so real. When I have an out of body experience, everything can be just as clear as it is in a dream. Everything is just as real as this. They're all metaphors in my interpretation. There are lots of out of body books that describe that, and most of those are real experiences. Bob did indeed experience just what he wrote about. That was his experience. He just didn't see it as a metaphor. Everything's a metaphor. This experience, you see, is also like that. Everybody here is going to walk away with a different reality of what happened here. Everyone is going to have their own version of what this was, what I said, what it meant. It's going to be different for everyone. Certain parts you'll agree with, but a lot of things you'd say, really? That happened? I didn't get that at all. You see, everybody's going to have a different reality here. We think we're all living

questioner: When reading books about out-of-body experiences, how should one interpret the experiences described by the authors? Should they be seen as literal representations of reality or as metaphorical interpretations of their experiences?
agent: I don't understand that at all. You see, each person has their own unique reality. We may think we're all experiencing the same fixed reality, but that's not the case. We're actually living in our own individual realities. That's the distinction. So when you read Bob's books or any other books about out-of-body experiences, it's important to interpret them as metaphors. That's how the authors perceive and convey their experiences. This is one of the reasons why I choose not to discuss my own experiences. There's little benefit in doing so. My experiences are my own metaphorical interpretation. If I were to share my metaphor with you now, you would enter that state of mind and expect to see exactly what I described, assuming that's what exists. By doing that, I would only make it more challenging for you to discover your own reality. I would unintentionally hinder your progress. Therefore, there's no point in sharing. Bob unintentionally did something similar with his park. He had a park where he would go to relax during his out-of-body experiences. It had trees, a beautiful lawn, and other elements that made it a soothing environment for him. However, people still try to visit Bob's Park. But that park was Bob's personal creation. Why did it have trees and grass? Because, to Bob, that was what constituted a relaxing environment. Someone else's idea of relaxation could be completely different. For example, being in the woods with falling debris from the trees may not be relaxing at all. They might prefer being in a rowboat in the middle of a serene lake during sunset. Everyone's park is unique, and what brings relaxation and peace varies from person to person.

questioner: When reading books about out-of-body experiences, how can one understand the diverse interpretations individuals bring to their own unique experiences?
agent: I find it quite relaxing to know that different parks offer unique experiences. For instance, Bob's Park is a place where people gather and engage in various activities. It's fascinating how individuals can come together and bring their own interpretations to life. Bob has done an excellent job of describing this phenomenon, and it's not about making things up but rather perceiving the park in their own way.

agent: Yes,  that's another virtual reality. They're all virtual realities. It just has a different purpose and a different kind of rule, set the.

questioner: Interaction  with the parent as well. Like when you go back to, I guess the larger consciousness, that's done.
agent: No,  when you as a free will awareness unit kind of re. You can you can say join or you could say it has your data. You can just be deleted as a free will awareness unit can just go delete because all the data is already back there to the however you want to say that. You can say you're merged. It sounds better to merge than it does to be deleted. But that's emotional thing, it's the same idea. All the information gets back to the parent. The parent takes that and tries to learn what it can learn from it because it can compare that to other things and see patterns that otherwise you can't see just in a single lifetime. So you have that is kind of emerging now. This individuated unit of conscious stays an individuate unit of consciousness. There's no need for it to merge. It's got more lives to do it's, learning it's on this path.
